prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Factors militating against transfer—The trial court has denied a § 1404(a) transfer motion

para.paratext: The Panel may consider the trial court's previous denial of a motion for change of venue under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) in deciding the transfer question. The Panel has always recognized that the two motions do not present the same issues and do not dictate the same result.[1] Nonetheless, the Panel has stated that it would consider the denial of a motion to change venue and the reasons stated by the trial court.[2] Similarly, the fact that a trial judges has already transferred one action to another district under § 1404 may militate in favor of global transfer by the Panel. The Panel has certainly looked to 1404 transfer decisions in selecting a transferee district.[3] In another case, the Panel seriously questioned the motive by counsel for plaintiffs in advanced action seeking transfer of four newly-filed actions where transfer would offer no obvious benefit to the class and might only benefit class counsel.[4] The Panel does not readily question the motives of counsel, however, and generally rejects arguments from counsel questioning their adversaries' motives.[5]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Radioshack Corp. “ERISA” Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2007). The comparison of transfer concerns with those of venue are discussed in §§ 3:4 and 5:9.
See In re American Financial Corp. Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1232, 1234 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
See, e.g., In re Air Crash Near Edgartown, Mass., on October 6, 2000, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
In re Louisiana-Pacific Corp. Trimboard Siding Marketing Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2012).
See, e.g., In re Wright Medical Technology, Inc., Conserve Hip Implant Products Liability Litigation, 844 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2012).
